title: Jeremiah Chapter 41 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 41 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 41 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 41.

questions.question: Who came to Gedaliah at Mizpah in the seventh month according to Jeremiah 41?
options: Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and ten men
Johanan the son of Kareah and his captains
Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.correctAnswer: Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and ten men
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:1 states that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and ten men came to Gedaliah at Mizpah to eat bread together.

questions.question: What did Ishmael and the ten men do to Gedaliah in Mizpah?
options: They smote him with the sword and killed him
They made a treaty with him
questions.correctAnswer: They smote him with the sword and killed him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:2 explains that Ishmael and the ten men smote Gedaliah with the sword and slew him.

questions.question: Who were slain by Ishmael along with Gedaliah at Mizpah?
options: All the Jews with Gedaliah, the Chaldeans there, and the men of war
questions.correctAnswer: All the Jews with Gedaliah, the Chaldeans there, and the men of war
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:3 states that Ishmael slew all the Jews with Gedaliah, the Chaldeans, and the men of war present at Mizpah.

questions.question: From which places did fourscore men come to Mizpah with offerings and incense?
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:5 mentions that men came from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria with offerings and incense to the house of the LORD.

questions.question: How did Ishmael greet the men coming from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria?
options: Weeping and inviting them to Gedaliah
questions.correctAnswer: Weeping and inviting them to Gedaliah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:6 tells that Ishmael went out weeping and invited them to Gedaliah.

questions.question: What did Ishmael do to the men from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria when they entered the city?
options: Slew them and cast them into a pit
questions.correctAnswer: Slew them and cast them into a pit
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:7 states that Ishmael slew these men and cast their bodies into a pit.

questions.question: Why did Ishmael spare ten men among those from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria?
options: Because they pleaded and said they had treasures in the field
Because they promised to serve him
questions.correctAnswer: Because they pleaded and said they had treasures in the field
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:8 explains that ten men asked not to be slain because of their treasures of wheat, barley, oil, and honey, so Ishmael spared them.

questions.question: What was the pit where Ishmael cast the slain men originally made for?
options: For fear of Baasha king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: For fear of Baasha king of Israel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:9 states that the pit was made by Asa king of Judah for fear of Baasha king of Israel.

questions.question: Where did Ishmael take captive the remaining people of Mizpah after killing Gedaliah?
questions.correctAnswer: To the Ammonites
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:10 indicates that Ishmael carried the captives away to go to the Ammonites.

questions.question: Who led the forces that pursued Ishmael after he took the captives?
options: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan the son of Kareah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:11 and 41:12 show that Johanan the son of Kareah and captains went to fight Ishmael.

questions.question: True or False: Ishmael escaped from Johanan with eight men and went to the Ammonites.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:15 confirms that Ishmael escaped with eight men to the Ammonites.

questions.question: True or False: Johanan and his forces took back the remnant of the people from Ishmael after Gedaliah was slain.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:16 records that Johanan took the remnant of the people whom Ishmael had carried away captive.

questions.question: True or False: The people who returned with Johanan went to dwell in the habitation of Chimham by Bethlehem.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:17 states that they dwelt in Chimham near Bethlehem.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Now it came to pass in the ______ month, that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah came to Gedaliah.'
questions.correctAnswer: seventh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:1 specifies that these events happened in the seventh month.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Because of the Chaldeans: for they were afraid of them, because Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had slain ______.'
options: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah the son of Ahikam
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:18 explains the fear of the people because Ishmael had slain Gedaliah, the governor appointed by Babylon.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 41 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 41 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to trust leaders after betrayal. Based on Jeremiah 41, what biblical truth would you share about faith and trust?
options: We should trust God above all leaders, even when leaders fail
Leaders are always trustworthy and should never be questioned
One should avoid all leaders to prevent being hurt
Trusting only human wisdom leads to peace
questions.correctAnswer: We should trust God above all leaders, even when leaders fail
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:2-3 shows Gedaliah was appointed by the king of Babylon, yet he was betrayed and killed. This teaches believers to place ultimate trust in God rather than fallible human leaders (Jeremiah 41:2, 41:3, 41:18).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 41 teach us about perseverance through trials when facing betrayal and loss?
options: Remain steadfast in faith even when facing severe trials
Give up faith when circumstances become difficult
Seek revenge immediately to restore justice
Isolate yourself to avoid further pain
questions.correctAnswer: Remain steadfast in faith even when facing severe trials
questions.explanation: Despite the massacre and captivity (Jeremiah 41:3, 41:10), Johanan and the remnant continued to seek safety and hope (Jeremiah 41:14-18), showing perseverance in hardship.

questions.question: A believer asks how to respond to the temptation of revenge. Based on Jeremiah 41, what biblical principle can be shared?
options: Leave justice to God rather than taking revenge
Return evil with evil to teach a lesson
questions.correctAnswer: Leave justice to God rather than taking revenge
questions.explanation: The chapter records Ishmael’s violent revenge (Jeremiah 41:2-3), which brought fear and division (Jeremiah 41:18). The text implies the destructive nature of revenge, encouraging believers to trust God’s justice.

questions.question: How does this passage teach about humility and contentment in the face of fear and uncertainty?
options: Trusting God's protection leads to peace despite fear
Fear should be ignored and suppressed at all costs
Pride helps protect oneself in times of danger
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God's protection leads to peace despite fear
questions.explanation: The people fled to Egypt out of fear (Jeremiah 41:17-18), yet the situation shows the need for humble trust in God rather than fleeing in panic.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness for those who have hurt them. What does Jeremiah 41 teach about reconciliation and love for neighbors?
options: Reconciliation requires patience and trusting God’s timing
Hate and bitterness are the only responses to betrayal
Avoid all people who have caused pain forever
Love is only for those who treat you well
questions.correctAnswer: Reconciliation requires patience and trusting God’s timing
questions.explanation: Though the chapter highlights betrayal and violence (Jeremiah 41:2-7), Johanan’s efforts to restore the remnant (Jeremiah 41:11-16) show a move toward healing and restoration, demonstrating patience and hope.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 41 encourage believers in stewardship and honesty regarding possessions?
options: Be honest and protect what God has given you
Use deceit to keep treasures safe
questions.correctAnswer: Be honest and protect what God has given you
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 41:8, ten men plead for their lives because they have treasures in the field, showing the importance of valuing and honestly managing God’s provision.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 41, what does this passage teach about prayer and personal devotion during times of crisis?
options: Continuing devotion to God is essential even in hardship
Prayer is unnecessary when leaders fail
Worship should be stopped during danger
Only public prayers matter in crises
questions.correctAnswer: Continuing devotion to God is essential even in hardship
questions.explanation: Verse 5 shows men coming with offerings and incense to the house of the LORD despite the turmoil, illustrating the importance of maintaining devotion and prayer (Jeremiah 41:5).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 41 shows that God approves of Ishmael’s violent actions against Gedaliah and the people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The chapter records Ishmael’s violent killing of Gedaliah and others (Jeremiah 41:2-3), which led to fear and flight (Jeremiah 41:18), indicating these actions were harmful and not approved by God.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 41 encourages believers to flee from all danger without seeking God’s guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Though the people fled to Egypt out of fear (Jeremiah 41:17-18), the passage implies this was due to fear rather than trusting God, which is not encouraged as the best response.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 41 teaches that even after betrayal and hardship, believers should ________ and trust God’s protection.
questions.correctAnswer: persevere
questions.explanation: The remnant under Johanan’s leadership continued on despite danger (Jeremiah 41:14-16), showing the need to persevere and trust God’s protection (Jeremiah 41:18).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 41 model biblical integrity and honesty in leadership?
options: Gedaliah was appointed governor and trusted to lead righteously
Ishmael deceived and killed without integrity
Leaders should seek power by any means
Dishonesty is acceptable for political gain
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah was appointed governor and trusted to lead righteously
questions.explanation: Gedaliah was appointed by the king of Babylon as governor (Jeremiah 41:2), showing God’s provision of leadership, though he was later betrayed, highlighting the value of integrity in leadership.

questions.question: A believer is facing fear of persecution. According to Jeremiah 41, what practical advice would you give about dealing with such fear?
options: Trust God and seek fellowship for protection and encouragement
Run away from all problems without seeking help
Respond to fear by isolating oneself
Ignore the fear completely and pretend it doesn’t exist
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God and seek fellowship for protection and encouragement
questions.explanation: Johanan gathered the remnant and sought to protect them (Jeremiah 41:11-16) and they dwelt together despite fear (Jeremiah 41:17-18), illustrating the importance of trust and fellowship.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 41 teach about the importance of community and church life in times of crisis?
options: Believers should gather and support one another in hardship
Everyone should fend for themselves alone
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should gather and support one another in hardship
questions.explanation: Men came to Mizpah with offerings (Jeremiah 41:5), and Johanan gathered the remnant to protect and support them (Jeremiah 41:14-16), emphasizing community and fellowship.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 41 illustrate the biblical teaching on humility in leadership?
options: Gedaliah accepted his role as governor under Babylon’s authority humbly
Ishmael arrogantly took power by force
Leaders should always assert dominance aggressively
Pride is necessary for leadership success
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah accepted his role as governor under Babylon’s authority humbly
questions.explanation: Gedaliah’s position was given by the king of Babylon (Jeremiah 41:2), showing humility in submitting to God-ordained authority, contrasting Ishmael’s violent arrogance.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 41, what does this passage teach about the role of prayer and worship in difficult times?
options: Prayer and worship remain vital even amid turmoil
Worship should be halted during danger
Prayer is only for times of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer and worship remain vital even amid turmoil
questions.explanation: Despite the violence and fear, men came to the house of the LORD with offerings and incense (Jeremiah 41:5), highlighting the importance of continued devotion.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 41 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 41.

questions.question: Who was the leader that assassinated Gedaliah, the Babylonian-appointed governor?
questions.correctAnswer: Ishmael the son of Nethaniah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:2 states that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and the ten men with him rose up and killed Gedaliah.

questions.question: What royal lineage is Ishmael said to belong to, highlighting the political tension in the narrative?
questions.correctAnswer: Seed royal
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:1 identifies Ishmael as the son of Nethaniah, of the seed royal, indicating his royal lineage which adds to the political complexity.

questions.question: What was the significance of the pit into which Ishmael cast the slain bodies, and who originally made it?
options: It was made by Asa king of Judah for protection against Baasha king of Israel
It was a Babylonian prison pit
A natural cave used for sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It was made by Asa king of Judah for protection against Baasha king of Israel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:9 explains that the pit was originally made by Asa king of Judah for fear of Baasha king of Israel, highlighting a historical defensive measure repurposed here.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people when Johanan and his forces confronted Ishmael and his men?
options: They sought refuge in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They were glad
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:13 states that when the people saw Johanan and his forces, they were glad, indicating their preference for Johanan's leadership over Ishmael's violence.

questions.question: What reason is given for the people deciding to dwell in Chimham by Bethlehem instead of remaining in Judah?
options: Because they feared the Chaldeans after Gedaliah was slain
questions.correctAnswer: Because they feared the Chaldeans after Gedaliah was slain
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:18 explains that the people dwelt in Chimham near Bethlehem and intended to go to Egypt because of their fear of the Chaldeans following Gedaliah's assassination.

questions.question: Which city did Ishmael and his men come to meet Gedaliah, where the assassination took place?
questions.correctAnswer: Mizpah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:1 and 41:2 describe that Ishmael came to Mizpah where Gedaliah was eating bread and where the assassination occurred.

questions.question: The group from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria who were killed by Ishmael had what distinctive physical signs indicating mourning or penitence?
options: Beards shaved, clothes torn, and cuts on themselves
Clean shaven and dressed in white
questions.correctAnswer: Beards shaved, clothes torn, and cuts on themselves
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:5 describes these men as having shaved beards, torn clothes, and having cut themselves, which are traditional signs of mourning or penitence in ancient Near Eastern culture.

questions.question: How many men accompanied Ishmael when he came to murder Gedaliah?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten men
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:1 mentions that Ishmael came with ten men to Mizpah to see Gedaliah.

questions.question: What was the fate of the king's daughters and the remaining people in Mizpah after Ishmael's attack?
options: They were taken captive by Ishmael
They were killed by the Chaldeans
questions.correctAnswer: They were taken captive by Ishmael
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:10 states that Ishmael carried away captive the king's daughters and all the people who remained in Mizpah.

questions.question: Which group did Ishmael attempt to join after escaping from Johanan?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ammonites
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:15 records that Ishmael escaped with eight men and went to the Ammonites.

questions.question: True or False: Johanan the son of Kareah killed Ishmael after learning about his deeds.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:15 shows Ishmael escaped from Johanan with eight men to the Ammonites, so Johanan did not kill him.

questions.question: Why did ten men among the group beseech Ishmael not to kill them?
options: Because they had treasures in the field
They were priests of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had treasures in the field
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:8 recounts that ten men pleaded with Ishmael not to kill them because they had treasures of wheat, barley, oil, and honey in the field.

questions.question: The narrative's mention of offerings and incense in the hands of the mourners from Shechem and Shiloh suggests what about their intent?
options: They intended to worship at the house of the LORD
They planned to initiate a rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: They intended to worship at the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:5 describes the men coming with offerings and incense to bring to the house of the LORD, indicating a religious intent despite the political turmoil.

questions.question: How does the killing of Gedaliah by Ishmael reflect a typology of political betrayal found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It foreshadows Judas' betrayal of Jesus
It parallels David's betrayal by Saul
It is similar to Samson's conflicts with the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Judas' betrayal of Jesus
questions.explanation: The assassination of Gedaliah by Ishmael, a trusted leader, foreshadows the betrayal of Jesus by Judas, highlighting themes of political and personal treachery in Scripture.

questions.question: What is the literary significance of the pit used to dispose of the slain, considering its historical origin?
options: It serves as a symbol of judgment and historical foreshadowing
It is a random detail with no deeper meaning
It represents a burial place for kings
It was a common place for feasts
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a symbol of judgment and historical foreshadowing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:9’s note that the pit was made by Asa for protection against Baasha connects historical defense with contemporary judgment, creating a literary device of foreshadowing and irony.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 41 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 41 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who was appointed by the king of Babylon as governor over the land, according to Jeremiah 41?
options: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.correctAnswer: Gedaliah the son of Ahikam
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:2 states Gedaliah was the governor appointed by the king of Babylon. This reflects God's sovereignty over earthly rulers (Daniel 2:21), and the importance of God's people submitting to governing authorities (Romans 13:1-2).

questions.question: What act of treachery did Ishmael the son of Nethaniah commit against Gedaliah?
options: He slew Gedaliah with the sword
questions.correctAnswer: He slew Gedaliah with the sword
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:2 describes Ishmael killing Gedaliah, illustrating the human capacity for sin and betrayal (Psalm 51:5). This murder disrupted God's plan for peaceful governance, reflecting the brokenness of humanity apart from redemption (Romans 3:23).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 41, what was the fate of the Jews and Chaldeans who were with Gedaliah at Mizpah?
options: They were all slain by Ishmael
They were taken captive to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They were all slain by Ishmael
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:3 recounts that Ishmael killed all Jews and Chaldeans with Gedaliah, demonstrating the tragic consequences of sin and betrayal. This echoes the motif of violence against God's people seen in 2 Chronicles 36:16 and foreshadows Christ's suffering (Isaiah 53:7).

questions.question: What was the significance of the pit where Ishmael cast the slain men?
options: It was made by King Asa for fear of Baasha
It was a burial site for kings
It was a prison for rebels
It was a sacred temple pit
questions.correctAnswer: It was made by King Asa for fear of Baasha
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:9 explains the pit was originally made by Asa for defense. This shows the recurring human fear and need for protection from enemies, pointing to the ultimate security found in God (Psalm 46:1) rather than worldly means.

questions.question: Who pursued Ishmael after he carried captive the remnant from Mizpah?
options: Johanan the son of Kareah and the captains of the forces
Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan the son of Kareah and the captains of the forces
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:11-12 states that Johanan and his captains fought Ishmael, reflecting the human response to injustice and the pursuit of justice (Proverbs 21:15). This also highlights God's providence in preserving a remnant (Isaiah 10:20-22).

questions.question: How did Ishmael respond when he encountered men from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria who came to Mizpah?
options: He invited them to Gedaliah and then killed them
He welcomed them and protected them
He sent them back to their homes
questions.correctAnswer: He invited them to Gedaliah and then killed them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:6-7 describes Ishmael weeping to lure the men, then killing them, illustrating hypocrisy and deceitfulness as fruits of sin (Psalm 55:23). This contrasts with Christ's call for genuine repentance and love (Matthew 22:37-39).

questions.question: Why did ten men among those from Shechem plead with Ishmael not to kill them?
options: They had treasures in the field
questions.correctAnswer: They had treasures in the field
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:8 shows these men spared because they possessed resources, reflecting human concern for material wealth even amid crisis. This contrasts with biblical teaching on trusting God rather than riches (Matthew 6:19-21).

questions.question: Where did Ishmael flee after escaping from Johanan?
questions.correctAnswer: To the Ammonites
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:15 records Ishmael fleeing to the Ammonites, indicating alliances outside Israel, often viewed as opposition to God's covenant people (Psalm 83:6-8). This flight shows the instability caused by sin and rejection of God's plan.

questions.question: What was the response of the people Ishmael had captured when they saw Johanan and the captains?
options: They were glad and returned to Johanan
questions.correctAnswer: They were glad and returned to Johanan
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:13-14 shows the people rejoiced seeing Johanan, illustrating God's providential preservation of a remnant and the joy of deliverance (Psalm 126:1-3). This aligns with God's promise to restore His people (Isaiah 11:11-12).

questions.question: What was the ultimate destination chosen by Johanan and the remnant after recovering them from Ishmael?
options: They dwelt in Chimham near Bethlehem, intending to go to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: They dwelt in Chimham near Bethlehem, intending to go to Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:17 reveals their plan to go to Egypt out of fear of the Chaldeans, demonstrating a lack of trust in God's protection (Psalm 20:7) and foreshadowing future reliance on God rather than worldly refuge (Exodus 14:13-14).

questions.question: What was the reason the people were afraid and fled to Egypt rather than trusting the king of Babylon's appointed governor?
options: Because Ishmael had slain Gedaliah, the governor
Because of a famine in the land
Because of an invasion by Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Because Ishmael had slain Gedaliah, the governor
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 41:18 explains the fear caused by Ishmael's murder of Gedaliah, leading to distrust in Babylonian authority. This reflects human fear in the face of sin and chaos, underscoring the need for faith in God's sovereign plan (Psalm 56:3).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the overall theme of Jeremiah 41 regarding human nature and divine sovereignty?
options: Human treachery contrasts with God's control over historical events
Human righteousness ensures peace and security
Divine judgment is absent in human conflicts
God endorses human rebellion against rulers
questions.correctAnswer: Human treachery contrasts with God's control over historical events
questions.explanation: The chapter shows sinful human actions—murder, deceit (Jeremiah 41:2-7)—amid God's providential orchestration of events (Jeremiah 41:11-14). This aligns with Romans 8:28 and God's ultimate control despite human sinfulness.

questions.question: How does the murder of Gedaliah in Jeremiah 41 relate to the biblical doctrine of the remnant?
options: It initiates the scattering of God's people and highlights preservation of a faithful remnant
It ends the existence of God’s people
It leads to the immediate restoration of Israel
It signifies the rejection of God's covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It initiates the scattering of God's people and highlights preservation of a faithful remnant
questions.explanation: The killing of Gedaliah caused dispersion (Jeremiah 41:10, 41:18), yet Johanan's recovery of some reflects God's preservation of a remnant (Isaiah 10:20-22, Romans 11:5), a key biblical theme of salvation history.

questions.question: What theological lesson about trusting human leaders versus God is underscored by the events in Jeremiah 41?
options: Trust in God rather than unstable human rulers is essential
Rebellion against rulers is always justified
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God rather than unstable human rulers is essential
questions.explanation: The murder of Gedaliah and the people's flight to Egypt (Jeremiah 41:18) demonstrate failure to trust God's provision. Scripture teaches ultimate trust belongs to God (Psalm 118:8), not fallible human leaders (Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: What role do the actions of Johanan in Jeremiah 41 play in the broader biblical narrative of salvation history?
options: He acts as a restorer of the remnant, preserving God's covenant people
He leads a rebellion against God
He abandons the people to their fate
questions.correctAnswer: He acts as a restorer of the remnant, preserving God's covenant people
questions.explanation: Johanan's efforts to rescue captives (Jeremiah 41:11-16) align with God's ongoing preservation of a faithful remnant (Zephaniah 3:13, Romans 11:5), integral to God's redemptive plan culminating in Christ.
